comment_data.body:
Let's leave some breadcrumbs, for now. We can decide later how to present/word it.

```
- Locate the first parent dir containing a "node_modules" dir: >
  vim.fs.find('node_modules', { path = root_dir, upward = true })
>
  - Note: The old `util.find_node_modules_ancestor` API is deprecated and will be removed.
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -297,9 +297,6 @@ below returns a function that takes as its argument the current buffer path.
 - `util.find_git_ancestor`: a function that locates the first parent directory
   containing a `.git` directory. >
    root_dir = util.find_git_ancestor
-- `util.find_node_modules_ancestor`: a function that locates the first parent

comment_data.body: Tbh we already write that `find_...` is deprecated in favor of `vim.fs.find` in the top of the section so I guess I can just revert it and leave it be for now?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -297,9 +297,6 @@ below returns a function that takes as its argument the current buffer path.
 - `util.find_git_ancestor`: a function that locates the first parent directory
   containing a `.git` directory. >
    root_dir = util.find_git_ancestor
-- `util.find_node_modules_ancestor`: a function that locates the first parent

comment_data.body: The code snippet in the above example was helpful for me. It really helps not to have to track this stuff down later, why don't we just leave a breadcrumb? It is zero-cost.

-- `util.find_node_modules_ancestor`: a function that locates the first parent

comment_data.body: I think you misunderstood, I was agreeing with you about leaving a breadcrumb. Your suggestion sounds fine, let's go with that ðŸ‘

comment_data.body:
one thing to note. I remember there was an issue about util.find_node_modules_ancestor

```
mkdir -p /home/mike/test/a/node_modules
mkdir /home/mike/test/node_modules
```

run `:lua print( require'lspconfig'.util.find_node_modules_ancestor('/home/mike/test/a'))` the result shouldbe test not a

so does there  need `limit =math.huge` with a stop and return the last item in the result list ?  ðŸ¤”
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -405,4 +388,14 @@ function M.path.exists(filename)
   return stat and stat.type or false
 end
 
+--- @deprecated use `vim.fs.find('.hg', { path = startpath, upward = true })` instead
+function M.find_mercurial_ancestor(startpath)
+  return vim.fs.find('.hg', { path = startpath, upward = true })
+end
+
+--- @deprecated use `vim.fs.find('node_modules', { path = startpath, upward = true })` instead
+function M.find_node_modules_ancestor(startpath)
+  return vim.fs.find('node_modules', { path = startpath, upward = true })

comment_data.body: Oh wow, so the first "root marker" we find might not be the actual root marker? That's fucked up lol. OK, will test it out, thanks for the heads up.

comment_data.body:
i forget mentioned that currently are also not correct . so maybe we can fix it on this refactor something like 

```lua
  local resulst = vim.fs.find('node_modules', { path = startpath, upward = true, limit =math.huge, stop = vim.env.HOME })
 if #result > 2 then
      -- if find more and last is $HOME return #result - 1 should be root
    return { result[#result - 1] }

```

comment_data.body: Related https://github.com/neovim/nvim-lspconfig/issues/1908. Took me some time to find it. I closed the issue because the original author did not respond. The plan is to fix it during the refactoring. So when I saw this PR, I thought of this issue. Of course, it can also be fixed in another PR.  not a big problem because there are only a few similar issues but  solved at the workspaceFolder level. But it is a bit strange that some of them do not support worksapceFolder .  it's fine.

comment_data.body: I think that issue seems more about the documentation of `find_node_modules_ancestor` rather than any problems it has as a helper function related to `lspconfig`. I think the `find_node_modules_ancestor` behaves "correctly" in that it seems to do what most people/servers expect. I could be wrong, but my interpretation is that we don't need to "fix" anything in this case.

comment_data.body:
> I think the find_node_modules_ancestor behaves

emm I think it should return test instead of test/a , servers that support workspaceFolder, if you open test first and then open the file in a, the server will be reused. There is no problem here. Most people do this. But if you open a first and then open the file in test, it will be messed up. However, this is an isolated case, but it is still a problem.

comment_regular_data.body: @justinmk should we wait for the minimum supported version to be 0.10 before we do this because of `vim.fs.root`? Right now, the replacement we can use is `vim.fs.find('node_modules', {path='/Users/dundargoc/test/a', upwards=true})[1]`
next will return key and value .. `vim.F.if_nil(unpack(result))` or  current behavior is always first item so just next(result) ~= nil and result[1] or nil

OK, I think this should work in all instances:

```lua
vim.fs.find('node_modules', {path='/Users/dundargoc/test/a', upwards=true})[1]
```

Still, it's not pretty.
yeah .but it work ðŸ˜Š can improve on next fix `test` not `test/a`

> hould we wait for the minimum supported version to be 0.10 before we do this because of `vim.fs.root`? Right now, the replacement we can use is `vim.fs.find('node_modules', {path='/Users/dundargoc/test/a', upwards=true})[1]`

No, let's move forward with this. But let's also mention `vim.fs.root` in the "breadcrumbs" note "if you have Nvim 0.10 or newer".
